While Christopher Columbus' reputation has suffered greatly, and perhaps excessively, under historical review it should be pointed out that the notion that he alone believed the world was round while all the learned men of the day told him it was flat is an early 18th century fantasy.

The truly revolutionary ideas that made his voyages possible (at least in his own mind) consisted of a new estimate of the diameter of the Earth and an unconventional estimate of the size of Asia. In both cases Columbus' numbers disagreed greatly with the commonly accepted numbers of the day, what "science" knew at the time. Of course we now know that the commonly accepted numbers of the day were much, much closer to reality.

If the Americas had not been there Columbus would be an obscure footnote in history, a name on small a monument in southwestern Spain bearing the epitaph "I really thought we would have been there by now."

The biggest problem with the Mars One project is that it relies on getting enough funding from a world population that is far too incredulous despite so much scientific evidence to demonstrate that a mission like this is relatively cheap and easy to pull off compared to the extreme and very necessary benefits it provides to all of us. I am skeptical about the mission because I doubt they will be able to convince enough of you suckers to believe in it.

After spending 23 pages explaining why sending people on a one-way trip to Mars is neither cheap nor easy (or even particularly desirable), there are still gullible folks to support the idea. Quite amazing.

Cheap or easy is relative. What seems very difficult for one person can be much easier and cheaper than the stuff large corporations manage all the time. Now a Mars colony is expensive no matter how you look at it, no one corporation on Earth is capable of shelling out that kind of money on a whim, yet there are still larger expenditures on almost a yearly basis so it's not even remotely outside the realm of possibility.
